sentences.sentence: Ontario's children and youth returned to in-person schooling this fall, after having missed a minimum of 26 weeks of in-person schooling over the past two academic years.

These closures, albeit initially considered necessary to curtail the spread of COVID-19, were not inconsequential to the well-being of children and youth.Indeed, there is now clear evidence of harms associated with the loss of in-person schooling.

Efforts can and should be made this academic year to maintain in-person learning wherever possible, utilizing testing strategies to minimize at-home quarantine following a close contact exposure in the classroom.School closures have had significant impacts on students' physical and mental health, social and emotional well-being, and academic performance.

When children and youth are out of school, their activity levels drop, their screen time increases, their sleep deteriorates and we start to see increasing rates of obesity, which correspond with chronic illnesses later in life.The impact of school closures on children's mental health has been profound, with increases in self-reported loneliness and symptoms of depression and anxiety.

Rates of eating disorders have climbed and utilization of acute care mental health services has grown.According to a recent report by the Royal Society of Canada(https://rsc-src.ca/sites/default/files/C%26S%20PB_EN_0.pdf), education disruptions have led to decreased academic engagement, credit attainment and academic achievement, as well as chronic attendance problems.School closures have also negatively impacted caregivers and overall family functioning.
When schools are closed or cohorts are dismissed, caregivers' ability to work is affected and stress in the home increases.
Parents report greater difficulty in managing emotions and behaviour, especially when quarantined at home.Increased conflict has been noted between family members.

Parental stress, in turn, intensifies emotional and behavioural issues in children, making it hard for parents to be sensitive to their children's needs, and increasing the use of harsh parenting and child maltreatment as a result.This new academic year presents an opportunity for recovery and growth for schoolchildren.
We need to prioritize in-person schooling and minimize prolonged classroom closures and student absenteeism.

Tools such as rapid antigen tests (RATs) have been studied to understand whether their use can safely facilitate a "test-to-stay" strategy, where children and youth remain in the class following a close contact exposure, while participating in regular rapid antigen testing over the course of the isolation period.RATs are an effective tool to detect COVID-19 in those with or without symptoms.
These tests can be conveniently performed at home or at school and do not require any special skill to administer.
They are less expensive than lab tests and the results are available quickly.RATs are one type of rapid point-of-care test and are currently approved for use in Ontario in those who are asymptomatic.

A recent study(https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(21)01908-5/fulltext) published in the Lancet found that daily testing of school-based contacts was equivalent to self-isolation for the control of COVID-19 transmission, with similar rates of symptomatic infections among students and staff found using both approaches.

Overall, this study showed that infection rates in school-based contacts were low, with very few school contacts testing positive.Earlier data out of Utah(https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/70/wr/mm7021e2.htm) supported the use of RATs in schools to identify infections and sustain in-person instruction.
From January to March 2021, 13 high schools conducted 14 test-to-stay events, performing a total of 14,531 tests and yielding a positivity rate of 0.7 per cent.

After testing events, these 13 schools continued in-person schooling, collectively saving 109,752 in-person instruction days for students.There is growing evidence to suggest that children and youth can safely remain in the classroom after a close contact exposure.
Furthermore, in-school COVID-19 transmission is infrequent.

We now know that loss of in-person schooling has detrimental effects on the education and overall well-being of many children and youth.School-based COVID-19 screening using RATs for close contact exposures, in order to minimize at-home quarantine, is a feasible means of sustaining in-person schooling.
Ontario's children and youth need us to continue to adjust our strategies for mitigating the spread of COVID-19, while also prioritizing their well-being.
Both are possible.National PostTess Clifford is a clinical psychologist specializing in children and youth in Kingston, Ont.
Martha Fulford is a pediatric and adult infectious diseases physician in Hamilton, Ont.
Alanna Golden is a general practitioner with a background in children's mental health counselling in Toronto.
Tracy Vaillancourt is a Tier 1 Canada research chair in school-based mental health in Ottawa.Paul W. Bennett: Should we close schools during the coronavirus epidemic?
